> it seems to me that these methods does not test transitivity of 
> equals, which is declared in Java Specification.

assertEquals() checks two objects for equality according to the equals() 
method. It is not designed to test the validity of your equals() method; 
quite the opposite, it relies on the correctness of your equals() method.

You may be looking for an "Equals Tester": a class that tests that your 
implementation of equals() forms an equivalence relation on objects of your 
class. That you would have to build yourself. I wish I had one in a common 
package to offer you, but I don't.

 I think 
> documentation should state that assertEquals(p1,p2) is completely 
> equiv to assertTrue(p1.equals(p2)) am i right? assertEquals public 
> static void assertEquals(java.lang.String message,                   
>              java.lang.Object expected,                              
>   java.lang.Object actual)  Asserts that two objects are equal. If 
> they are not an AssertionFailedError is thrown.

I believe assertEquals(o1, o2) essentially does this:

if( o1 == null ) {
    assertTrue(o1 == o2);
}
else {
    assertTrue(o1.equals(o2));
}

If it doesn't, then I think I'd better look at the source again, because 
that's what I expect it to do.
